title: Inconsistent behavior of _.merge
body:
Hello,

I have a question because i have an inconstistent behavior on my lodash (`"4.17.10"`)
```
_.merge({roles:['a']}, {car: 1, roles:['b']})

{roles: Array(1), car: 1}
car: 1
roles: ["b"]
```

```
_.merge({roles:['a']}, {car: 1, roles:['b', 'd']})
{roles: Array(2), car: 1}
car: 1
roles: (2) ["b", "d"]
```

is it by design ?

title: Idea - would love a debouncedFunction.resolve() method to cut short the wait
body:
Thanks for maintaining this awesome library awesome lodash team! I use it for everything!

Regarding `_.debounce`...

Similar to `myDebouncedFunction.cancel()`, it would be awesome if we could manually tell the function to resolve instantly instead of waiting for the rest of the timeout.

Maybe something like `myDebouncedFunction.resolve()`

When it resolves, it could resolve with the same resulting output as if we waited for the timeout to end.

Any thoughts?

title: add PascalCase
lodash _.add function version issue
_.chain mutates implicit lodash objects
body:
Calling `_(obj)` creates an implicit lodash chain. Calling `_.chain(obj)` creates an explicit one. 

But in the following snippet, the original chain is mutated instead of merely being wrapped:
```
let original = _(obj);
let wrapped = _.chain(original);
```
In this scenario, `original` will have to explicitly call `.value()` because it was modified to become an explicit chain.

lodash/fp extends doesn't work with multiple sources
body:
Looks like _.assignIn doesn't work as it's documented.

When I try to pass multiple sources like `_.extend({a:1}, [{c:3}, {a: 2, c:1}])` the output is 
```
{
  "0": { "c": 3 },
  "1": { "a": 2, "c": 1 },
  "a": 1
}
```
but should be
```
{
  a: 2,
  c: 1
}
```

Looks like a bug for me. Probably the same issue is happening with some other similar functions like _.defaults, _.merge

Tested in http://dexters-lab.io/ with lodash versions 4.17.4 and with 4.17.11

Thanks in advance

title: Template does not escape ES template literals
body:
About version 4.17.11

although the `template` function allows using ES template literals it does not allow it to be escaped. Case in point:

With lodash's template:
```javascript
let lodashTemplate = _.template('\${foo}')({foo: 'bar'}); 
console.log(lodashTemplate); // prints 'bar'
```

With template literals:
```javascript
let foo = 'bar';
let esTemplate = `\${foo}`;
console.log(esTemplate); // prints '${foo}'
```

Is this a bug or does `template` not allow to escape template literals (as it can be disabled with a custom interpolator function)?

See the `device_timestamp` for both, how after cloning it gets modified.

title: Feature Request: callback in _.get when defaultValue is used
body:
I didn't see anything like this in the issue tracker so apologies if this has been requested before and I didn't find it.

Basically I would like an optional 4th parameter to the _.get function that would be a callback function that would be invoked when the default parameter is used.

The goal would be especially in development that I could hook a logger or other error handler in to alert me when my get is failing and I could see before pushing to production if I've mistyped a path that will always end up with the defaultValue being used.

So the new function signature would look like

```javascript
/**
 * Gets the value at `path` of `object`. If the resolved value is
 * `undefined`, the `defaultValue` is returned in its place. If the `onDefault` callback is passed, it is
 * invoked with the other parameters
 *
 * @since 3.7.0
 * @category Object
 * @param {Object} object The object to query.
 * @param {Array|string} path The path of the property to get.
 * @param {*} [defaultValue] The value returned for `undefined` resolved values.
 * @param {Function} [onDefault] Callback invoked when defaultValue is used. Receives `object`, `path`, and `defaultValue` as parameters.
 * @returns {*} Returns the resolved value.
 * @see has, hasIn, set, unset
 * @example
 *
 * const object = { 'a': [{ 'b': { 'c': 3 } }] }
 * const onDefaultCb = (obj, path, default) => console.warn(`default value ${default} used, could not resolve path ${JSON.stringify(path)}, for ${JSON.stringify(obj)}`)
 * get(object, 'a[0].b.c')
 * // => 3
 *
 * get(object, ['a', '0', 'b', 'c'])
 * // => 3
 *
 * get(object, 'a.b.c', 'default')
 * // => 'default'
 *
 * get(object, 'a.b.c', 'default', onDefaultCb)
 * // => 'default', warning logged to console by onDefaultCb
 * @returns {*} Returns the resolved value.
 * @see has, hasIn, set, unset
 * @example
 *
 * const object = { 'a': [{ 'b': { 'c': 3 } }] }
 *
 * get(object, 'a[0].b.c')
 * // => 3
 *
 * get(object, ['a', '0', 'b', 'c'])
 * // => 3
 *
 * get(object, 'a.b.c', 'default')
 * // => 'default'
 */
function get(object, path, defaultValue?, onDefault?) {
  const result = object == null ? undefined : baseGet(object, path)
  if (result === undefined) {
    if (onDefault) onDefault(object, path, defaultValue)
    return defaultValue
  }
  return result
}
```

There is no sideEffects: false field in `node_modules/lodash/package.json`, only this
```
{
  "name": "lodash",
  "version": "4.17.11",
  "description": "Lodash modular utilities.",
  "keywords": "modules, stdlib, util",
  "homepage": "https://lodash.com/",
  "repository": "lodash/lodash",
  "icon": "https://lodash.com/icon.svg",
  "license": "MIT",
  "main": "lodash.js",
  "author": "John-David Dalton <john.david.dalton@gmail.com> (http://allyoucanleet.com/)",
  "contributors": [
    "John-David Dalton <john.david.dalton@gmail.com> (http://allyoucanleet.com/)",
    "Mathias Bynens <mathias@qiwi.be> (https://mathiasbynens.be/)"
  ],
  "scripts": { "test": "echo \"See https://travis-ci.org/lodash-archive/lodash-cli for testing details.\"" }
}
```

so webpack cant tree-shake lodash (no one uses him but it's still in bundle)

repro

- open `node_modules/lodash/package.json`
- no `sideEffects: false`

title: Support arrow function in debounce
map: add optional third argument to specify accumulator object
body:
At present, map is basically a special case reduce, where the acc object is always an array. Sometimes it would be nice to use map on objects and return another object

An example of how I would like to use it:
```js
const a = {a: 'a', b: 'b'}
const b = _.map(a, val => val + 'c', {})  // => {a: 'ac', b: 'bc} instead of ['ac', 'bc']
```
At present the most convenient way to accomplish this general type of transformation (as far as i can tell) is:
```js
const b = _.assignWith({}, a, (xx, val) => val + 'c') // placeholder variable needs to be included
```
Another option is the even lengthier:
```js
const b = _.transform(a, (acc, value, key) => {
  acc[key] = value + 'c'
}, {})
```

In the end, I feel like the syntax would look a little cleaner for a use-case that seems to pop up every now  and then, and backwards compatibility would be maintained.

title: Use string as object in _.set or _.setWith
body:
Hi everyone!
If we run
```js
_.set({},[ 'data', '2019', 0, 'price' ], 'zzz',)
```
**we get:** 
object -> array -> array -> object

**I want to get:**
object -> object -> array -> object

So String '2019' will be treated as index of array, not as key of an object.
Is it possible to use with _.set or _.setWith so that any string type like '2019' (even it can be coerced to number) will be treated as object key, and any number type as array index? 

I tried some variants like this, but it makes number 0 key of an object too.
```js
_.setWith({},[ 'data', '2019', 0, 'price' ], 'zzz', (nsValue, key, nsObject) => {
  if(!nsValue) {
    if (typeof key === 'string') return {}
  }
})
```

title: How intersectionWith() compares arrays?
lodash/fp and JsDelivr
body:
Hi guys,

I noticed that the example of FP-guide (https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide) with JsDelivr use an old link which is not maintained anymore: https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/g/lodash@4(lodash.min.js+lodash.fp.min.js)

As you can check, the version served by this URL is `4.17.4` and does not exist for version `4.17.11`: https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/g/lodash@4.17.11(lodash.min.js+lodash.fp.min.js)

Indeed the last pull request on JsDelivr repo is for `4.17.4`: https://github.com/jsdelivr/jsdelivr/issues?q=lodash+sort%3Acreated-desc

We could use the new JsDelivr way to combine libraries if `lodash.fp.js` and `lodash.fp.min.js` were published on npm registry: https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/combine/npm/lodash@4.17.11/lodash.min.js,npm/lodash@4.17.11/lodash.fp.min.js

What do you think about publishing `lodash.fp.js` and `lodash.fp.min.js` too?

title: rename flattenDepth to flat #3998
Behavior of orderBy when there are "unsortable" values in "desc" order?
body:
Hello, I am using lodash to sort items with a property that can be `NaN` or a `Number`.

Due to the current architecture, I can not provide my own compare function to handle NaN [1].
By default, `orderBy` / `sortBy` puts NaN values at the end of the array [2]. It is fine.

**But, items going at the end of the array only works with `asc` order.**
If I use `desc`, `NaN` is kind of treated like "+infinite" and so, all unsortable values are at the beginning of the array. 

```
const items = [{v:NaN}, {v:1}, {v:3}, {v:2}]
 
> _.orderBy([items, ['v'], ['asc'])
[ { v: 1 }, { v: 2 }, { v: 3 }, { v: NaN } ]

> _.orderBy([items], ['v'], ['desc'])
[ { v: NaN }, { v: 3 }, { v: 2 }, { v: 1 } ]
```

**Thoughts / solutions**
Could we have some options for orderBy or a different behaviour?
Either always put "unsortable values" at the end regardless of sort order (`asc`, `desc`), or have an option to decide? Maybe the ability to provide a default value?

Note that this is probably specific to `orderBy` because `sortBy` always use `asc` to sort. But I feel that we are on an edge case that might happen more often than thought.

In my case, I need to simply sort a list or orders in a ledger but sometimes values can be missing and I'd like to control where I want the missing values to be sorted: at the beginning, at the end or at the "center" when it makes sense.

Related: 
* https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3718 (Sorting function contract with sortBy) [1]
* https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3718 (Consistent order with NaN with sortBy) [2]

title: isEmpty is not working with FormData
Curry fixes + tests for issue #3981
body:
## What does this PR do?

In a ***curry***, placeholder values were sometimes being passed to the original function like below:

```js
const triples = _.curry((a, b, c) => [a, b, c]);
triples(_, 2, _)(_, 3)(_, 1); // => [f, 2, 3]
triples(_, 2)(_, 3)(_, 1);    // => [f, 2, 3]
triples(_, 2)(3, _)(_, 1);    // => [f, 2, 3]
// Where f === lodash (placeholder)
```

Expected:

```js
const triples = curry((a, b, c) => [a, b, c]);
triples(_, 2, _)(_, 3)(_, 1);   // => triples
triples(_, 2, _)(_, 3)(_, 1)(1) // => [1, 2, 3]
```

Also, ***curry*** was taking into consideration arguments that were outside of the arity of the original function like below:

```js
const pairs = _.curry((a, b) => [a, b]);
pairs(1, _, 0) // => [1, "__lodash_placeholder__"]
```

Expected:

```js
const pairs = _.curry((a, b) => [a, b]);
pairs(1, _, 0);                       // pairs
pairs(1, _, 0)(2);                    // => [1, 2]
pairs(1, _, 0, 5, 50)(_, _, _, _)(2); // => [1, 2]
```

Issue: #3981

title: Sort object by string-keyed property names
throttle should be always executed asychronously
_.over* enhancements
body:
Two simple suggestions for the `_.over*` Utility functions (`_.over`, `_.overEvery` and `_.overSome`):
1. All of these currently take an array as there one and only argument. Could these functions also accept multiple arguments in lieu of an array? It would simplify the syntax a bit (for instance, in one case I have: `_.remove(args, _.overSome([_.isRegExp, _.isString]))` -- it'd be nice to ditch the square brackets.

2. In addition and/or instead, would it be possible for the `_.over*` functions to accept an optional value to process and -- if one is provided -- return the result of the that value passed to the function that is currently returned?
 
    In other words, if it would be nice to be able to call (assuming the first suggestion is also implemented) `_.overSome(arg, _.isRegExp, _.isString)` and get a truthy value returned. This could be done by checking if the first (or last, depending on your preference) argument is not a function (and either the other arguments are functions -- assuming my first suggestion -- or else there is exactly one other argument and it is an array). In the case where the value to be checked is a function as well, the intent can be clarified by passing the functions in an array as the second argument.

title: Proposal: _.thunk
Proposal: fromPairsBy
body:
Not sure if this is the best method name but I think it would be handy to have a function that takes an array, a function to extract the key from each element, and a function to extract the value from each element, and creates an object from the extracted key/value pairs.  I'm happy to make a PR, just wanted to get your approval before I spend time on it.

Here's what the method would look like:
```
> fromPairsBy([{key: 'a', value: 1}, {key: 'b', value: 2}], x => x.key, x => x.value)
{a: 1, b: 2}
```
With property shorthand it's fantastic:
```
> fromPairsBy([{key: 'a', value: 1}, {key: 'b', value: 2}], 'key', 'value')
{a: 1, b: 2}
```
I started wanting this while seeking to transform the following AWS output:
```
$ aws cloudformation describe-stacks --stack-name clarity-db --query 'Stacks[0].Outputs'
[
    {
        "OutputKey": "DBInstance",
        "OutputValue": "clarity"
    },
    {
        "OutputKey": "RecordSet",
        "OutputValue": "redacted"
    },
    {
        "OutputKey": "SecurityGroup",
        "OutputValue": "redacted"
    }
]
```
(wish I could pipe the output to `| lambduh 'json => require("lodash").fromPairsBy(json, "OutputKey", "OutputValue")'`)

FP version:
```
> fromPairsBy('key', 'value')([{key: 'a', value: 1}, {key: 'b', value: 2}])
{a: 1, b: 2}
```
The shortest way I know of to do this with existing API is not too bad but a bit more cumbersome (and requires ES2015):
```
> fromPairs([{key: 'a', value: 1}, {key: 'b', value: 2}].map(({key, value}) => [key, value]))
{a: 1, b: 2}
```

title: Wrong document description at cloneDeepWith API
body:
This API: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.10#cloneDeepWith.
I think the description should be : "This method is like _.cloneWith except that it has a call back function." instead of "This method is like _.cloneWith except that it recursively clones value." because cloneWith  API also do recursively clones value.

title: --save no longer needed
body: `--save` is on by default as of [npm 5](https://blog.npmjs.org/post/161081169345/v500), so `npm install aphrodite` is functionally equivalent to `npm install --save aphrodite` now

title: Partial placeholder present as curried function argument
body:
When currying with placeholders, the placeholder value is sometimes passed to the original function:

```js
const triples = _.curry((a, b, c) => [a, b, c]);
triples(_, 2, _)(_, 3)(_, 1); // => [f, 2, 3]
triples(_, 2)(_, 3)(_, 1);    // => [f, 2, 3]
triples(_, 2)(3, _)(_, 1);    // => [f, 2, 3]
// Where f === lodash (placeholder)
```

Expected:
```js
triples(_, 2)(_, 3)(_, 1);    // => triples
triples(_, 2)(_, 3)(_, 1)(1); // => [1, 2, 3]
```

However, this works:
```js
triples(_, 2)(_, 3)(_)(1); // => [1, 2, 3]
```

This seems to be an issue when the arity of the function is exceeded and maybe placeholders are considered in some arity calculation?

Another strange example:
```js
const pairs = _.curry((a, b) => [a, b]);
pairs(1, _, 0) // => [1, "__lodash_placeholder__"]
```

Here I would expect the `0` to be ignored, since it is "outside" the arity of the original function and the curried function to be returned, allowing for:

```js
pairs(1, _, 0)(2) // => [1, 2]
```

*Lodash Version 4.17.10*
*Chrome Version 68.0.3440.106*

title: _.set does not work when an array exists along the path
currying added to add.js
_.defaultsDeep can mutate source at some cases
body:
Please see https://plnkr.co/edit/J7svOBeIMZKnvLelzUya?p=preview

There is a moment and lodash example. Currently I was not able to reproduce it with any other objects.

After running the next code: 
`_.defaultsDeep({}, a, b);`
`console.dir(a);`

We can see that in the source `a.settings.min` has all the properties that the appropriate `moment` object has, including the ones from its prototype. Also please note, that somehow `max` object does not go to the `a.settings.max`, so this looks like a problem with rewriting only existing properties.

title: Fix comments of sortBy's result.
body:
Hi,

While I was reading docs I found results of sortBy were little bit different.
So I fixed what I checked out.
If I was wrong just tell me. 😄

title: isJSON Method
body:
We know that `object` type may include several things but for confirming whether the object is JSON-like, having `isJSON` method is necessary.

There should not be any error regarding test and style but the importance of this matters, and I think by most `_` users this method is going to be loved.

Thanks in advance!

title: _.snakeCase Unexpected Behavior?
body: According to #561 and this [comment](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/561#issuecomment-43519167), it seems like something like `address1` should be considered its own word and not be converted to `address_1`, but it is. Did the behavior change at some point or am I misunderstanding something?

title: No REPL in docs provided for Firefox
body:
When visiting the documentation website, there is no "Try in REPL" provided inside the examples for Firefox. In Chrome I have this option. Is this intended or not? 

Website: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.10
Chrome: 69.0.3497.100 (64-Bit)
Firefox: 62.0.2 (64-Bit)

title: Feature request: _.builder()
Why is _.throttle its own function?
map iteratee in lodash/fp doesn't receive object key
body:
I haven't tested other functions, only map, and only with objects. It might occur with others as well.

The below function outputs `[undefined]`:

```js
var obj = {
    a: 2
}

map((value, key) => key, obj)
```

The normal lodash counterpart works as expected.

Happens under lodash 4.17.11.

title: _.round/_.floor/_.ceil do not work under lodash/fp
body:
**lodash version:** ^4.17.11
**npm version:** 6.4.1
**node version:** 8.11.1

**Bug or feature ?** Bug

**Expected behaviour:**
```js
$ node
> const _ = require('lodash/fp');
undefined
> _.ceil(135020, -4)
140000
> _.floor(135020, -4)
130000
> _.round(135020, -4)
140000
```

**Actual behaviour:**
```js
$ node
> const _ = require('lodash/fp');
undefined
> _.ceil(135020, -4)
135020
> _.ceil(135020)(-4)
TypeError: _.round(...) is not a function
> _.floor(135020, -4)
135020
> _.ceil(135020)(-4)
TypeError: _.round(...) is not a function
> _.round(135020, -4)
135020
> _.round(135020)(-4)
TypeError: _.round(...) is not a function
```

Most likely this is due to introducing a fixed arity of 1 to the functions for the /fp version of the package.

title: Importing lodash.merge will bring most of lodash in my bundle

body:
fp/map((value, key) = ..., object)
Key is undefined

title: Equal By function
body:
Hello. While using lodash I decided that it will be great if there will be function that will provide functionality as equalBy. 

Examle: 
```
const x = { a: 1, b: 2};
const y = { a: 2, b: 2};

_.equalBy(x, y, 'a'); // false
_.equalBy(x, y, 'b'); // true
_.equalBy(x, y, el => el.a); // false
```

Name for the function could be eqBy, isEqualBy or equalBy.
Could I create PR for this feature?

title: Offline docs in Dash
body: Thank you for `lodash/fp`! There is this macOS app called [Dash](https://kapeli.com/dash), which allows people to have and search various docs offline (e.g. in a train, plane, ... and sometimes it's just faster to look up than the web versions). There's an official Lodash docset: There is no docset for the `lodash/fp` though. Would you consider [adding it](https://kapeli.com/docsets)? Also it looks like there is [other popular software](https://alternativeto.net/software/dashexpander/) which does the same thing, such as [Zeal](https://zealdocs.org/), so maybe the docset could be even compatible with those? I think the main problem is the FP part of lodash isn't even a part of your HTML docs. There's this [FP Guide](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide), but there are many differences and it’s very hard to search the regular docs and to just guess what the FP equivalent would be or to scan the FP guide for changes between those two. E.g. function `invokeArgs` doesn't even exist in the regular docs, but it’s crucial to know about it when you want to use `invoke` from FP. I spent hours figuring out this one in particular. Do you have any plan to extend the regular docs with a full FP documentation? That would be probably sufficient to solve my issue as I can imagine the documentation would bubble up to the official docset.
